[GAME] Starting a new 10-round Texas Hold'em game with 2 players.
[GAME] ===== Hand 1 / 10 - Pre‑flop =====
Pot: 30 | Current bet: 20
Visible board: []
P0 (Dealer/BB): 990.00 chips | bet 10.00 | active
P1 (SB): 980.00 chips | bet 20.00 | active
Your hole: A♦, 3♦
==============================================
rounds.response:
GENERATE KNOWLEDGE
1. Pre-flop ranges in heads-up play  
   • With blinds 10/20 and 1 000-chip stacks, effective stack depth = 50 bb (deep).  
   • The SB has position all the way (button), so his opening range should be ~40-45 % of hands.  
   • The BB (Hero) is out of position, so traditional re-steal range is narrower: roughly top 15-20 % (AA-TT, AK-AJs, KQ, suited connectors, good suited aces like A5s-A3s, etc.).  

2. Hand strength vs. range equity  
   • A♦3♦ is “ace-high suited wheel.” Versus a wide SB opening range (~45 %), it has ~47 % raw equity.  
   • High-card value matters: if SB misses the flop, an Ace on board often guarantees at least one pair.  
   • Flush-making potential: by the river we flop or backdoor into a flush ~11 % of the time and disguise it well in heads-up.  

3. Position & SPR considerations  
   • Out-of-position with initiative can be costly deep-stacked: harder to realize equity, villain can float flops.  
   • If we merely call, the pot will be 80 chips → SPR ≈ 12 effective after a call (990 effective). We have enough chips to maneuver post-flop, but any turn/river line still out of position.  

4. Aggression & ICM-free chip EV  
   • There’s no prize-pool jump, so pure chip EV > survival. Maximize pot share.  
   • A3s is a great 3-bet bluff because it blocks AX, reduces combos of AA, AK, AQ, and holds nut-flush potential.  

5. Sizing & stack depth  
   • Optimal 3-bet size out of BB vs SB 2.5x open: 2.3-2.5 pot → (20)*(2.5) = 50 chips.  
   • Leaves us: R ~940 effective; villain ~930. Still 47 bb behind if call, 44 bb if villain 4-bets small and we 5-bet jam flop.  

6. Psychological meta  
   • Early in 10-handed mini-match; we can create an “active” image, which pays dividends when we later have KK, AK, etc.  

CONCLUSION FROM KNOWLEDGE
A♦3♦ is at the very top of our OOP 3-bet bluff range. It has solid equity vs a wide SB range, excellent blockers to villain value 3-continuations, and huge playability with nut-flush outs. Folding is -EV given 30 % blind dead money. Calling is playable but forgoes initiative and leaves awkward post-flop spots OOP. Optimal choice is 3-bet.  

ACTION  
[Raise 50]

rounds.response:
[KNOWLEDGE]
1. **Hand Strength Analysis**: 6♣3♣ is one of the weakest possible starting hands (2nd worst unsuited, only 6-2o is worse). Even suited, it has poor high-card value, minimal straight potential (requires perfect 4-5-7 or 2-4-5 flops), and low flush draw viability (backdoor only). Equity against a typical BB raising range is ~22-24%.
   
2. **Pot Odds Calculation**: 
   - Current pot: 90 chips
   - Call cost: 50 chips (70 current bet - 20 already invested)
   - Effective odds: 90:50 = 1.8:1 → Requires 35.7% equity to profitably call (50 ÷ (90 + 50) = 35.7%)
   - Actual equity vs reasonable BB range (pairs+, A8+, KQ, etc.): ~23% → 12.7% equity deficit

3. **Positional Disadvantage**: As SB facing BB aggression, you'll be out of position (OOP) post-flop. This reduces hand viability by 10-15% due to inability to control pot size or bluff effectively.

4. **Reverse Implied Odds**: 
   - Hitting weak top pair (6x/3x) likely loses to stronger pairs.
   - Flush draws have low showdown value (e.g., 6-high flush loses to any higher club).
   - Minimal profit potential when winning vs high loss potential when losing.

5. **Tournament-Specific Factors**: 
   - Only 10 hands total: Chip preservation is critical.
   - 5% of stack at risk (50/980) with negative expectation.
   - Early hand fold maintains psychological equilibrium for later spots.

6. **Raise Size Significance**: 70-chip raise = 3.5x BB (larger than standard 2.5x) suggests strength, polarizing BB's range toward value hands (top 30% range).

[FOLD]

Generate Knowledge – Hand 2, heads-up, 10 bb effective, small blind vs big blind

1. Heads-up ranges widen dramatically
   • SB can open any two cards profitably vs random BB defend
   • BB gets 3:1 on a call (20 to win 30), so BB can defend ~70 % of hands
2. Stack-to-pot (SPR) after one bet is <2, so post-flop maneuverability is limited
3. Position
   • You (SB) have positional disadvantage post-flop; you act first
4. Hand strength
   • Q2o is bottom 20 % of hands
   • Equity vs random defend ≈49 % pre-flop
5. Tournament context
   • Chip EV only matters (no ICM) in heads-up freeze
   • 990 vs 970 effective (nearly even); no urgency yet

Decision tree:
   • [Fold] guarantees zero EV
   • Open-raise (standard 2.5× → total 70) needs 66 % folds or enough post-flop edge; with Q2o this is marginal vs loose BB defend
   • Open-limp (call 20) is exploitable vs BB who can check or raise; Q2o flops poorly
   • Jam (shove 990 to win 30) has terrible risk/reward and should be avoided

Evaluation: Q2o from SB is weak enough that folding is acceptable; raising is marginal without reads. Given lack of fold-equity vs unknown BB and positional disadvantage post, best line is:

[Fold]

Generate Knowledge  
Key poker principles / concepts for this spot:  

1. Position & Initiative  
   We’re in the big blind handing out a small blind, so we act second post-flop (position is decent). P1 checked back to us instead of raising pre-flop; this indicates he does not hold a strong premium hand, and has ceded initiative. Checking gives him a free flop; betting (a “probe” or delayed continuation-bet) re-claims the initiative and forces one decision out of him.

2. Hand Strength vs. Villain Range  
   K♦ 7♦ is in roughly the 35th percentile of starting hands—far ahead of any two random cards in terms of equity, but behind the range with which many players would 4-bet or raise pre-flop. Because P1 just called the big blind, his range is capped; dominated King-x hands (KJ-KT etc.) are partly discounted. Thus K7s dominates many hands (middling aces, queens, suited connectors) while only trailing pocket pairs and other kings.

3. Bet Sizing & Stack-to-Pot Ratio (SPR)  
   - Pot is 30 chips.  
   - Effective remaining stacks are 990 vs 980 (~980 effective), so our SPR is ~33, which is deep.  
   - A “standard” size to steal the pot while risking little is 65–75 % pot. 25–30 chips achieves two goals: (a) forces folds from hands that whiff totally; (b) builds the pot when villain might just have the top of his capped range (small pocket pairs, Q-high, suited connectors) that has to define hand strength immediately or fold.

4. Frequency Considerations  
   In heads-up short-stack play, aggression is paramount. Given only two players, a strong king-highenough hand with back-door flush/straight potential is a clear semi-bluffing opportunity; we should bet this a large majority of the time (>75 %). Checking back allows free realization of hands that could out-draw us while giving no information.

Evaluation & Decision  
Check keeps the pot small when out of position is unnecessary here because we actually have position once P1 checked. Instead, extracting value or taking it down outright is the better proactive play.  

I will bet 30 chips (~100 % of the pot) and force P1 to make a decision with his entire range.

[Bet 30]

1. Starting-hand value changes dramatically: K7s is a premium when 40 BB deep. Equity vs random ≈ 61 %.

3. Pot odds vs bet size: facing 90 to win 120 → 3-to-1 immediate. We only need ~25 % raw equity to call profitably if no later street action is considered.  
4. Stack-to-pot ratio (SPR): 970 behind : 120 pot ≈ 8:1. Medium stack allows either flat with implied odds or 4-bet to commit.  
5. Reverse implied odds of king-domination: P1 can hold AK/KQ/KJ, which lowers showdown value dramatically if we hit a king.  
6. Tournament ICM is minimal in a 2-player freeze-out, so chip-preservation is slightly less valuable; pressing small edges is acceptable.

- Calling costs 60 into 180 (effective pot 180) turning SPR ≈ 5.5; post-flop play out of position with reverse implied odds.  
- 4-bet shove (970 total) risks 910 to win 120; would only be profitable if villain folds ~45 % of 3-bet range. Likely overplay — villain already invested 90, folding frequency probably lower.  

K7s has enough equity versus opponent’s merged range (estimated 23-25 % if they semi-bluff light) to peel one street, but the reverse implied odds make a cold-call marginal. Given: we are ahead of draws, behind dominating kings, and have back-door equity with a suited king. Balanced line: see a flop in position while keeping pot controlled.

Generate Knowledge:

- Hand strength: Pocket Kings (KK) is the second-strongest starting hand in Texas Hold'em, only behind pocket Aces. It has excellent equity preflop against any range.
- Position: I am in the Big Blind (BB), and Player 0 is in the Small Blind (SB). After preflop, the SB acts first post-flop, so I have position post-flop, which is advantageous.
- Action so far: Player 0 raised from SB to 60 (a 3x initial raise), which is standard for a strong or semi-strong range. However, in a 2-player game, players may open wider from the SB.
- My options: I can call, raise (resurrect the action), or fold. Folding KK is almost never correct preflop, especially out of position.
- Pot odds: The pot is 70, I need to call 50 more (since I’ve already posted 10), so my call costs 50 to win 70, giving me ~58% required equity to justify a call. KK has far more than that.
- Implied odds: If I raise or call and hit a set (very unlikely since I already have a pair of Kings), I can win a big pot. But we’re already at a high equity point.
- Reverse implied odds: If an Ace flops, I may be up against AA and lose a big pot; however, KK dominates most other hands (QQ, JJ, AK, AQ, etc.).
- Raising for value: With such a strong hand, I should raise to build the pot and protect my hand. A flat call could be exploited by more aggressive opponents and may allow draws or weaker hands to get cheap turns.
- Expected frequency of Aces: Player 0 raised from SB—could they have AA? Possible, but unlikely. AA is rare (0.45% chance), and they’d likely play it similarly. Still, I must assume a reasonable range including hands like AK, AQ, TT+, possibly suited connectors.
- Re-raising preflop: Standard play with KK is to 3-bet (re-raise) for value and protection. A typical 3-bet size in this context would be 2.5x to 3x the original raise. Original raise was 60, so 3-bet to 150–180 is standard.
- Stack-to-pot ratio (SPR): After calling, SPR would be low if we go all-in preflop (~14 after 150 raise), but we’re only on hand 6, so tournament pressure is low. Still, preserving chips while maximizing value is key.
- Fold equity: If I raise to, say, 150, Player 0 may fold weaker hands like AK, AQ, or smaller pairs, which I dominate. While we want value, we also want to avoid thinning the field too much unless we are certain of dominance.
- However: Since KK performs best against multiple opponents and we are heads-up, we want to build the pot.

Conclusion: The optimal play is to raise significantly to extract value and protect the hand. A re-raise to 150 or 180 is standard. Since we are in BB and already have 10 in, raising to 150 means adding 140 more chips (total bet = 150). But in poker, when we say "raise to", we mean the total bet.

Valid syntax: "[Raise N]" where N is the total bet amount (not the additional amount). So to make it 150 total, I must “[Raise 150]”.

Player 0 bet 60, so I have to put in 60 to call. To raise, I must make it at least double the previous raise (from 20 to 60 is +40, so a minimum raise would be +40 more, to 100). But I can raise more.

Standard 3-bet size: 2.5x to 3x opponent’s raise. 3x 60 = 180. So raising to 180 is natural.

We have 1050 chips, so 180 is affordable.

Therefore: The correct action is to raise to 180 for value and hand protection.

Decision: none of the fold lines have positive EV compared with calling and realizing the full equity of 33 with good SPR. A 4-bet is too thin because we are at the bottom of our continuing range.

[Call]

rounds.response:
Generate Knowledge: Strategy in short-stack, 10-hand 2-max with blinds 10/20.

1. Starting-stack matters & ICM simplification: With only 10 hands, “loss of life” <> chips – folding away rounds hurts more later.  
   • P0 now has 720 vs P1 1250 – we’re the short stack (36BB) facing an 83BB opponent. Avoiding marginal losses is slightly more important than high risk/high reward plays because the chip lead compounds on future streets.

2. Positional dynamics:  
   • P0 is BB (bigger blind) for this hand, so out of position post-flop.  
   • Pre-flop the effective pot is already 30 (small blind 10, big blind 20). UTG (our villain, small blind) has chosen to complete rather than raise (== limps 10 into 20). Next street SB will have position after we check the big blind.

3. Hand evaluation:  
   • Q♣ A♣ (nut suited) is a premium holding.  
   • Against a ~100 % limping range from SB villain (who until now has shown aggression with big re-raises on 8♣8♠Q♣, etc.) AQ suited crushes ~65-70 % of that range; against accurate 2-max SB limp range we have ~61 % equity.  
   • With deeper stacks (>~50BB) a mixed strategy would include both a raise and a check strategy here. But with 36BB we prefer a linear 3-bet sizing to punish limps and dominate their calling range.

4. Bet-size: Short-stack rule of thumb is to pick a raise amount that allows an easy stack-off if villain 4-bet jams. Rough guideline: 3-bet to ~35% of remaining stack.  
   • 35 % of 720 ≈ 250. Need to decide between 200-250 keeping turn SPR at 1 if we are called and see flop. A 200-220 sizing generally suffices – doesn’t quite commit us fully on flop but keeps shove unprofitable for villain's bluffs.

Applying the above:

KQ suited type hands often re-polarize smaller sizes; here we have literal nut suited powerhouse. Raising range – absolutely mandatory. Expect tough opponent might flat a lot or re-bluff. We choose a 220 sizing to leave villain ~1030 or 890 behind — good stack depth for optimal future streets.

Decision logic:

Did opponent cheap-flop us (limped range ~100%). Board texture much worse for us if we give free cards; we deny equity, exploit our relative premium. Leverage small stack worth a 3-bet here.

Player 0 action:  
[Raise 220]

rounds.response:
Generate Knowledge:

- **Hand Strength**: Pocket Kings (KK) is the second-strongest starting hand in Texas Hold'em, only behind pocket Aces. It has extremely high equity pre-flop against any range, especially against a loose raise.
  
- **Position**: I am in the Small Blind (SB), and my opponent is in the Big Blind (BB)/Dealer position. Being out of position post-flop is a disadvantage, but with such a strong hand, this is less concerning.

- **Opponent’s Action**: The opponent raised from the Big Blind (defensive position) to 240 chips, which is a large raise—12x the big blind. This indicates either a very strong hand (like AA or KK, though we hold KK), a semi-bluff with a strong suited connector, or a polarized/shove range given their stack.

- **Stack Sizes**: 
   - Opponent: Started with 490 chips after posting the big blind and raise. Their total commitment is 240, so they have 250 remaining.
   - Me: 1250 chips with only 20 invested. I have over 5x their remaining stack.

- **Pot Odds & Implied Odds**: Calling the additional 220 chips (to call 240, already have 20 in) would commit me to a large portion of my stack. However, with KK, we are likely ahead of any non-AA hand.

- **Fold Equity & Raise Potential**: Given the deep stack, a re-raise would put significant pressure on the opponent. Since their raise to 240 is large (pot-sized), it may represent strength, but also could be a shove attempt to take the pot pre-flop.

- **Risk of Overcards**: If we call and an Ace appears on the flop, it could cripple our hand’s perceived strength, especially out of position.

- **Effective Stack Dynamics**: Since the opponent is short-stacked relative to the raise size (less than 2x their raise), this may be an all-in or shove move. In fact, raising to 240 with only 490 total suggests they may be committed.

- **Poker Principle – Balancing Range**: While KK should usually 3-bet for value, in this case, facing a large raise out of position, we must decide whether to call, raise (shove), or fold. Folding KK is almost never correct unless facing a confirmed AA.

- **Best Play with KK**:
   - If facing a raise in early position or blind-vs-blind, standard play is to either 3-bet for value or go all-in, especially when stacks are shallow.
   - Here, since the opponent has raised to 240, and we have 1250, the effective stack after the raise is less than 2.5x the raise. This qualifies as a shallow stack scenario.

- **All-In Decision Logic**: 
   - With KK, going all-in pre-flop is highly profitable against any range except AA.
   - Opponent may be shoving lighter or with speculative hands.
   - Calling 220 to win a 260 pot gives poor immediate odds (~46% needed), but with equity, it’s marginal. However, **shoving over their raise (raising to 490 all-in)** has more value because:
     - It denies equity to hands like AK, QQ, JJ.
     - It builds the pot while ahead.
     - It may fold out weaker Ax or suited hands.

- **Fold to All-In Consideration**: If we shove, they must fold or call. If they have AA, we are about 18% to win. Against AK, QQ, etc., we are a significant favorite.

**Conclusion**: The optimal line is to raise all-in (to 490 total). This maximizes value and applies maximum pressure, especially since our hand dominates everything except AA. Given only one hand ago we had KK and now again, but frequency is low, and we must play optimally.

Action:

[Raise 470]

rounds.response:
Generate Knowledge
1. Heads-up ranges: In a 2-player game, VPIP (voluntarily-put-money-in-pot) ranges are much wider. Strong hands like AQs are premium and should play for stacks, but stack-to-pot ratio (SPR) of ≈ 1.4 is already “committed” if we call (effective 560 behind into 950 pot post-flop).  
2. Pot odds / equity: Getting 2.34 : 1 on a call (490 to win 950), we need only ~30 % equity. AQs vs typical heads-up wide 3-betting range (22+, A2s+, any suited broadway + some bluffs) has 55–60 % raw equity—even reduced to 40 % because of card removal it’s profitable to call.  
3. ICM / Tournament survival: Only three hands left, current stack 490 vs villain 560 basically identical with blinds rising—chip EV ≈ tournament EV here. Folding to preserve <49 bb makes zero sense when we can flip for tournament lead.  
4. Reraising all-in instead of flatting inflates pot even more and gives villain good odds to call, but still puts previous 710 in play; literally we must call 490 to contest 950.  
5. Construction: Villain’s sizing (5.5 × 3-bet) is polar—likely strongest hands or bluffs with blockers. Regardless, expect many dominated Ax and Kxs/QJs that miss flops.

Decision: Mathematics says call; fold is too nitty. Cannot reopen raise after villain’s overshove, so call is only option.

[Call]

rounds.response:
Generate Knowledge  

Current state:
• Stack sizes – P0: 20 chips (me, BB, no future fold-equity), P1: 560 chips  
• Pot 1 420 ‑- one of the largest of the match  
• Board: 10♣ 3♠ 9♥ rainbow, no possible flush yet  
• Hero holds Q♣ A♣ – overcards + back-door nut-flush draw (+ gut-shot Broadway if running J-K come)  
• No bet is currently live (both players checked). Effective remaining stacks are the 20-chip side-pot; main pot is frozen.

Key principles for this spot  
1. Stack-to-pot ratio (SPR) < 0.02 – we are pot-committed; any action that puts chips in must be to maximize fold-equity only when a bet leaves fold-equity. Otherwise we simply realize equity because we cannot be hurt further.  
2. With <1 BB behind, fold equity is virtually nil; checking behind or betting 20 when effective stack is 20 are almost identical in EV: we are free-rolling for the pot.  
3. Hand strength vs perceived villain range: villain 3-bet large pre-flop, then checked 100% pot flop. Polar range assumption: overpairs (AA-TT), some AK/AQ, and complete air as a bluff. Our ace-high may actually be ahead if villain bricked; any pair of tens beats us right now, but we have 6 outs (any Q or A gives top pair) + runner-runner royal/ Broadway possibilities.  
4. Tournament equity calculation – even though stacks are shallow, losing the hand gives finality (we bust). Winning catapults us back into contention.

Apply knowledge  
Because there’s literally 1 BB left and villain already checked flop, we cannot be bluffed off; nor can we make opponent fold anything that is currently beating ace-high. The only question: do we shove the last 20 or check behind and attempt to realize equity on turn+river? Shoving 20 into 1 420 does not create fold equity but incurs no additional risk (we’re already all-in except for a technical chip difference). Checking behind guarantees we see some equity realization and might prompt villain to (mistakenly) bet turn if a brick falls.

However, the rule is we must act – check is available and valid action.

Decision  
[Check]

Generate Knowledge:

- Stack Sizes & Commitment: With the flop pot at 1420 and both players having less than that in chips (P0 has 20, P1 has 560), the effective stack is now very shallow. P0 is effectively all-in for 20 chips, meaning they cannot fold profitably unless facing a large bet.
- Position: I am out of position (OOP) as the SB, which is a disadvantage when checking back and trying to control the pot. However, once the turn comes, with P0 checking again, they are showing weakness.
- Board Texture: The board is 10♣, 3♠, 9♥, J♦ — a coordinated, straight-friendly board. A ten through jack gives a straight (10-J-Q-K-A or 9-10-J-Q). However, my two kings remain very strong here, as it beats any top pair (like A-K, A-Q, K-Q), and only a straight (Q-K would need Q-8 or K-Q-A for wrap) or a set would beat it. Notably, sets are unlikely given P0’s pre-flop behavior (they raised to 240 cold, which suggests strength, but then checked both flop and turn — indicative of a bluff or missed hand like A-K or A-Q).
- Bet Sizing & Protection: With a strong hand like kings on a draw-heavy board, a value-bet is justified. However, P0 only has 20 chips left. If I bet more than that, they can only call with 20 — so I gain no extra value from betting more than ~20. Betting large is inefficient and risks inducing a bluff-catch from a weaker hand that might fold to a large bet.
- Check-Raise Strategy: Since P0 is very short-stacked, a check-raise doesn't make sense — if I check, they can at most raise by 20, so I don’t gain extra value.
- Pot Control vs Value Extraction: Given I have a strong hand and the opponent has shown extreme passivity (checking twice with only 20 chips), I should maximize value. However, the maximum value I can extract from P0 is 20 chips (their entire stack). Therefore, a small bet around 20–40 is optimal to induce a call from hands like A-K, Q-Q, J-J (which they might have played aggressively pre-flop), or even draws that missed.
